column1: tessacrowley 161001656581 "2017-05-23 23:51:00 GMT" https://tessacrowley.tumblr.com/post/161001656581/paint-colors-designed-by-neural-network-part-2 "lewisandquark:  So it turns out you can train a neural network to generate paint colors if you give it a list of 7
column2: 700 Sherwin-Williams paint colors as input. How a neural network basically works is it looks atÂ a set of data - in this case
column3: a long list of Sherwin-Williams paint color names and RGB (red
column5: blue) numbers that represent the color - and it tries to form its own rules about how to generate more data like it.Â  Last time I reported results that were
column6: wellâ€¦ mixed. The neural network produced colors
column8: but it hadnâ€™t gotten the hang of producing appealing names to go with them - instead producing names like Rose Hork
column10: and Turdly. It also had trouble matching names to colors
column11: and would often produce an â€œIce Grayâ€ that was a mustard yellow
column13: or a â€œFerry Purpleâ€ that was decidedly brown. Â  These were not great names. There are lots of things that affect how well the algorithm does
column14: however. One simple change turns out to be theÂ â€œtemperatureâ€ (think: creativity) variable
column15: which adjusts whether the neural network always picks the most likely next character as itâ€™s generating text
column16: or whether it will go with something farther down the list. I had the temperature originally set pretty high
column17: but it turns out that when I turn it down ever so slightly
column18: the algorithm does a lot better. Not only do the names better match the colors
column19: but it begins to reproduce color gradients that must have been in the original dataset all along. Colors tend to be grouped together in these gradients
column20: so it shifts gradually from greens to browns to blues to yellows
column21: etc. and does eventually cover the rainbow
column22: not just beige. Apparently it was trying to give me better results
column23: but I kept screwing it up. Raw output from RGB neural net
column24: now less-annoyed by my temperature setting People also sent in suggestions on how to improve the algorithm. One of the most-frequent was to try a different way of representing color - it turns out that RGB (with a single color represented by the amount of Red
column26: and Blue in it) isnâ€™t very well matched to the way human eyes perceive color. These are some results from a different color representation
column27: known as HSV. In HSV representation
column28: a single color is represented by three numbers like in RGB
column29: but this time they stand for Hue
column31: and Value. You can think of the Hue number as representing the color
column32: Saturation as representing how intense (vs gray) the color is
column33: and Value as representing the brightness. Other than the way of representing the color
column34: everything else about the dataset and the neural network are the same. (char-rnn
column37: 50 epochs) Raw output from HSV neural net: And here are some results from a third color representation
column38: known as LAB. In this color space
column39: the first number stands for lightness
column40: the second number stands for the amount of green vs red
column41: and the third number stands for the the amount of blue vs yellow. Raw output from LAB neural net: It turns out that the color representation doesnâ€™t make a very big difference in how good the results are (at least as far as I can tell with my very simple experiment). RGB seems to be surprisingly the best able to reproduce the gradients from the original dataset - maybe itâ€™s more resistant to disruption when the temperature setting introduces randomness. And the color names are pretty bad
column42: no matter how the colors themselves are represented. However
column43: a blog reader compiledÂ this dataset
column44: which has paint colors from other companies such as Behr and Benjamin Moore
column45: as well as a bunch of user-submitted colors from a big XKCD survey. He also changed all the names to lowercase
column46: so the neural network wouldnâ€™t have to learn two versions of each letter. And the results wereâ€¦ surprisingly good. Pretty much every name was a plausible match to its color (even if it wasnâ€™t a plausible color youâ€™d find in the paint store). The answer seems to be
column47: as it often is for neural networks: more data. Raw output using The Big RGB Dataset: I leave you with the Hall of Fame: RGB: HSV: LAB: Big RGB dataset:  tag urself iâ€™m sandbork" False text

column1: tessacrowley 160516864646 "2017-05-10 15:31:09 GMT" https://tessacrowley.tumblr.com/post/160516864646/james-comey-firing-overview "edwardspoonhands: So youâ€™re confused about this whole James Comey thing but also care about America so want to be less confused? Come with me! James Comey was (until today) the Director of the FBI. A Republican appointed by Barack Obama in 2013. He made a lot of enemies in the Democratic Party when
column2: 11 days before the 2016 election
column3: he re-opened investigation into Hillaryâ€™s emails. Turned out nothing interesting was in those new emails
column4: and also that this probably did result in Hillary losing the election. Kinda uncool. Also turns out
column5: he did not announce that the FBI was looking into links between Trumpâ€™s campaign and the Russian Government. It is clear (though some still argue) that Russia actively worked to influence the outcome of the US Presidential election. They did this by hacking and releasing information on Hillary Clinton
column6: and by creating and promoting incendiary and false news stories online. The Obama Administration knew about this and got real mad at Russia
column7: basically kicking all of their diplomats out of the country and creating new sanctions. There are two main concerns that the FBI (and other agencies
column8: including congress) have been looking into. 1. Whether the Trump campaign was in communication with the Russians before or after the election to say that the Obama sanctions wouldnâ€™t last. (This would be bad. Basically actively working against the existing government of the United States
column9: which is illegal.) 2. Whether the Trump campaign actively worked with the Russians to time the release of negative information on Hillary Clinton. (This would be even worse. Both could be considered treason.) A number of people in Trumpâ€™s campaign and also his current team had conversations with Russian diplomats and lied about it. This includes Mike Flynn
column10: who definitely violated the law and who was fired for lying to VP Pence about it. It also includes Attorney General Jeff Sessions
column11: who agreed that he would not be involved in the Russia investigations because he lied under oath about it. The FBI has had an on-going investigation into this stuff the whole time
column12: and James Comey has been leading that investigation. Quick note
column13: a Grand Jury is a citizen panel that decides whether thereâ€™s enough evidence to try a case. These are usually secret
column14: in order to protect the people who might not be even brought to trial
column15: much less found guilty. But sometimes they need to gather information
column16: like documents or testimony. And they do this with court summonses called subpoenas. Well
column18: CNN reported that a Federal Grand Jury investigating Mike Flynn and the Trump Campaigns ties to Russia exists. That Grand Jury has issued subpoenas for more information
column19: indicating to experts a high level of seriousness to the investigation. Itâ€™s pretty clear that Trump campaign knows about this
column20: and as itâ€™s a Federal case
column21: it was likely overseen by the FBI director
column23: just before that story came out
column24: the Trump team decided that Comeyâ€™s treatment of Hillaryâ€™s emails was bad
column25: and fired him. The recommendation to fire Comey came from AG Sessions
column28: recused himself from the Russia investigation after lying under oath. To be clear
column29: both Sessions and Trump have previously praised Comey at length for his treatment of that investigation. The response from Dems and also many Reps has been shock. It is very concerning for a President to fire someone who is investigating him. This seems to have happened very quickly. Comey found out he was fired the same time as everyone else
column30: the letter Trump wrote to him was delivered to DC
column31: but Comey was in Los Angeles at the time. Of course
column32: the Deputy Director of the FBI is now in charge
column33: but Trump has the job of appointing a new director
column34: and has not made any sign that he has a list of candidates. This seems the sort of thing that most congressional lawmakers
column35: who have a mandate to check the power of the President
column36: should be very worried about. Many are calling for a Special Prosecutor
column37: who would be free to work without congressional approval
column38: to be appointed. Others want broad
column40: which would ensure someone who is not under Trumpâ€™s thumb. The power to grant these things lies with congress. A congress that is controlled by the Presidentâ€™s party
column41: but not by the President. And that is where we are. It is pretty convoluted
column42: thank you for taking the time to read. The controversial points in this are: 1 Whether the Russian government hacked Hillaryâ€™s emails (many Republicans say there is no proof while every intelligence agency in the US said that it was orchestrated by the Russian government. 2. Whether Jeff Sessions lied under oath or if he just misspoke or forgot that he had met with Russian officials. In any case
column43: he agreed to remove himself from the congressional investigation. 3. Whether the Trump Campaign investigation was the cause of Comeyâ€™s firing. The stated reason is that Comey â€œlost credibilityâ€ and damaged the reputation of the FBI by mis-handling the Clinton email investigation. Thatâ€™s as good as I can do
column44: it feels like itâ€™s a good deal more comprehensive and concise than most of what Iâ€™ve been reading. If it helped you
column45: please show it around. " False text

tessacrowley 159711183151 "2017-04-18 09:49:57 GMT" https://tessacrowley.tumblr.com/post/159711183151/vieillesoul-penfairy-the-reason-i-hate-the "vieillesoul: penfairy:  The reason I hate the â€œShakespeare didnâ€™t actually write Shakespeareâ€ theories so much is they seem to be inherently rooted in taking his works away from ordinary people. â€œThe son of a glovemaker could never have written these plays! Surely only an Aristocratic Intellectual
column2: like the Earl of Oxford
column3: could be responsible!â€œÂ  Honestly fuck off. Shakespeare was one of us. His plays were written for the masses. He was an ordinary man who captured the voice of the people and the depths of their emotions. We credit Shakespeare with making up words and phrases
column4: but whoâ€™s to say he wasnâ€™t writing down what he heard on the streets?Â ""But something as complex as Hamlet could never have been written by Shakespeare! It must have been the work of a nobleman!â€ Well guess what
column5: not only did he write it
column6: but he wrote it because thatâ€™s what his audience liked. The hordes of ordinary people consumed his deeply philosophical play about a young man musing over life and death and sin and they LOVED it.Â   Shakespeare was a crowd-pleaser and an entertainer
column7: and reason his work is so beautiful and poetic and philosophical (as well as bloody and sexual!) is because he was responding to popular demand. Most people attending the theatre were illiterate; they consumed literature by listening
column8: and this is one of the reasons why playwrights utilised iambic pentameter and rhyming schemes. Their dialogue is poetry
column9: and itâ€™s beautiful to listen to. The first time Romeo and Juliet meet
column10: their shared dialogue creates a sonnet. Imagine a commoner sitting in the crowd listening to that
column11: and it hits him like an arrow
column13: listen to the way these characters speak
column14: Â this is love at first sight.Â  Shakespeare was an ordinary man
column15: and the beauty and complexity of his works were fuelled largely by the appetite of ordinary people. Although plays could be written and performed for the aristocracy
column16: it was the hordes at the theatres that one had to keep happy. ThisÂ modern obsession with putting him on a pedestal and trying to make him high culture or inaccessible to ordinary people is just gross. This upstart crow will always be one of us
column17: and his work will always be for us.  Just to add on a bit
column19: and I remember once in college
column20: my linguist professor was discussing Shakespeare
column21: and how he created new words. She said that linguists have studied the languages of the 14th
column24: and theyâ€™ve basically come to the conclusion that Shakespeare didnâ€™t invent these new words
column25: at all. They theorize that he actually picked up these words from young women who would use them
column26: as slang speech. Slang speech in these centuries can be found in letters young women wrote to each other
column27: with the slang coming from them shortening words
column28: in order to write faster. Of course
column29: womenâ€™s ways of talking have constantly been looked down upon throughout society
column30: but hereâ€™s an article from Smithsonian
column31: discussing the fact that young women throughout history have shaped language
column32: and continue to do so. They say that what holds men back (men trail by about a generation) is the fact that they make fun of the way in which women talk. http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/teenage-girls-have-been-revolutionizing-language-16th-century-180956216/  Classism sneaks up on you
column33: it really does. It took me years to really start unlearning it.I have one very clear memory
column34: I was in elementary school or middle school
column36: and we were assigned to read a short prose piece about poverty. I remember really liking it. It had one passage that was very evocative and really made me love it and think about its message:  Poverty is an acid that drips on pride until all pride is worn away. Poverty is a chisel that chips on honor until honor is worn away. Some of you say that you would do something in my situation
column38: for the first week or the first month
column39: but for year after year after year?  Poverty is an acid. I am still impressed by that phrasing. (Incidentally
column40: I looked it up and the whole text of this piece is here if you want to read it.)Anyway
column41: when weâ€™d all read through it
column42: the teacher began the usual rigmarole of asking questions about it. Basic stuff
column43: since we were still pretty young. Name some metaphors she used
column45: who do you think this author is? I raised my hand.â€œSheâ€™s a poor woman
column46: â€ I said.I remember so vividlyÂ that my teacher chuckled. In that condescending
column47: isnâ€™t that cuteÂ sort of way.Â â€œWell
column48: she clearly got an excellent education
column49: didnâ€™t she? She writes so well
column50: â€ she said to me.Â â€œSo she canâ€™t be that poor.â€The rest of the class nodded; this made perfect sense to them. It didnâ€™t at first to me
column51: but if you keep repeating a lie long enough it feels like truth.It wasnâ€™t until years later that I realized how truly fucked up it was
column52: and how easy it was for my teacher to say it
column53: and for everyone to readily accept it.What precludes a poor person from being a talented writer? Why is an education so necessary for talent
column54: and how do you explain the greatest artists in history who didnâ€™t have one? And why is it so easy to assume these things?Years later
column55: I looked it up. Jo Goodwin-Parker wasÂ poor
column56: for a very long time. Fuck you
column57: Ms. Ellison. It took me years to crawl out of that classist bullshit you started by chuckling condescendingly at my correct and prudent observation." False text
